Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Microbial Community Assembly in Coastal Waters of the Western Antarctic Peninsula
Award.AbstractNarration: The Western Antarctic Peninsula (WAP) has experienced unprecedented warming and shifts in sea ice cover over the past fifty years. How these changes impact marine microbial communities, and subsequently how these shifts in the biota may affect the carbon cycle in surface waters is unknown. This work will examine how these ecosystem-level changes affect microbial community structure and function. This research will use modern metagenomic and transcriptomic approaches to test the hypothesis that the introduction of organic matter from spring phytoplankton blooms drives turnover in microbial communities. This research will characterize patterns in bacterial and archaeal succession during the transition from the austral winter at two long-term monitoring sites: Palmer Station in the north and Rothera Station in the south. This project will also include microcosm incubations to directly assess the effects of additions of organic carbon and melted sea ice on microbial community structure and function. The results of this work will provide a broader understanding of the roles of both rare and abundant microorganisms in carbon cycling within the WAP region, and how these communities may shift in structure and function in response to climate change. Results will be widely disseminated through publications as well as through presentations at national and international meetings. The research will provide training opportunities for both graduate and undergraduate students and will enhance international collaborations with the British Antarctic Survey.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: The Western Antarctic Peninsula (WAP) has experienced unprecedented climate warming and reduction in winter sea ice over the last 50 years, resulting in strong ecosystem impacts, but consequences on the assembly of microbial communities involved in the remineralization of primary production remain unknown. The goal of this project was to test the hypothesis that niche-based forces, not neutral ones, explain assembly of microbial communities in the WAP. We hypothesized that injection of organic matter as governed by patterns in primary production determine assembly and drive turnover in microbial communities. Understanding controls on assembly has practical and intellectual relevance for predicting climate warming impacts and addressing controversies in ecology. Two objectives were fulfilled during the project:

 

1. We characterized natural patterns in seasonal succession in diversity and composition of bacterial communities during the transition from winter to summer. Palmer Station was the focus of weekly to sub-weekly sampling over a 9-month period to determine temporal variation in bacterial succession as a phytoplankton bloom developed. Bacterial community structure and composition was determined using amplicon sequencing of the 16S rRNA gene V6 hypervariable region.

 

2. We experimentally determined the influence of spring phytoplankton blooms by adding dissolved organic carbon (DOC) to bacterial communities. Microcosm experiments (50 L) were conducted at both Palmer Station by placing winter and spring seawater in carboys with or without added DOC. DOC from phytoplankton exudates was added to test whether this addition elicited similar responses that we observed in the seasonal study.

 

Along with quantifying contextual data, such as chlorophyll a and bacterial production, high resolution temporal sampling of bacterial community composition was achieved down to genus resolution by sequencing the hypervariable V6 region of the 16S rRNA gene in 206 discrete samples on the HiSeq Illumina DNA sequencing platform. To test whether neutral or niche-based forces prevailed, community assembly was examined using the extensive 16S rRNA V6 dataset that was generated, in the context of seasonal changes in bacterioplankton communities. Responses of the community to environmental forcing was assessed using multivariate statistical tools.

 

Our work significantly advanced knowledge of bacterial community structure and function in the WAP by focusing on the seasonal transition, and applying next generation sequencing technology to discover patterns in the distribution and metabolic activities of abundant and rare microbial taxa. By characterizing microbial assembly, integrated with knowledge from environmental genomics and bacterial physiology, our research advanced understanding of the limits on microbial heterotrophic activity and carbon recycling in the WAP. Our research used a theoretical framework to provide novel insights into microbial community assembly, increasing its ecological impact. Our study took advantage of a climate and ecosystem change occurring at Palmer Station. We found that bacterial community composition was closely coupled to the onset and senescence of a major phytoplankton bloom that occurred in summer. Surprisingly, there were changes in the bacterial community that preceded major changes in phytoplankton biomass, suggesting feedbacks between bacteria and phytoplankton that may stimulate the phytoplankton bloom itself, in addition to the critical role of bacteria in recycling organic matter. We found evidence for priority effects in succession of bacterial communities that are linked to seasonal changes. Thus, interannual variability and climate change may impact bacterial seasonal succession in a previously unexpected manor based on timing and magnitude of the phytoplankton bloom.

 

Broader Impacts: The proposed activity enabled graduate training and funding for a graduate student who successfully completed her PhD during the project. A new upper level undergraduate/graduate Geomicrobiology course was taught by the co-PIs that integrated the biological and geochemical principles from the proposed research into the course. The project encouraged participation of underrepresented groups by mentoring a minority undergraduate student through partnering with the Leadership Alliance.
